description:
Amorphotheca resinae ATCC 22711 is a species of fungus that belongs to the phylum Ascomycota. It is a filamentous fungus that is known to be involved in the biodegradation of certain organic compounds, particularly those found in fuels and lubricants.

This fungus has a distinctive anamorphic (asexual) stage, which is characterized by the production of septate hyphae and conidia (asexual spores) that are formed on conidiophores. The teleomorphic (sexual) stage of this fungus has not been extensively studied.

Amorphotheca resinae ATCC 22711 is considered a significant microorganism in the context of hydrocarbon degradation, as it has the ability to utilize various petroleum-derived compounds as a source of carbon and energy. This property has made it a subject of interest in bioremediation and biotechnological applications related to the treatment of fuel-contaminated environments.

The strain ATCC 22711 is a well-characterized isolate that has been widely used in research and has contributed to the understanding of the physiological and genetic mechanisms underlying the biodegradation capabilities of this fungal species.
